Legal_Issue: Whether the officer's decision not to exercise discretion under section 76(3) was justified, transparent, and intelligible
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, section 76(3)
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant scored 65 points (2 below requirement); settlement funds exceeded minimums but were not discussed in CAIPS notes
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate error in decision
Legal_Rule: Officer may substitute evaluation if points are not sufficient indicators of economic establishment; no duty to provide detailed reasons for refusing discretion
Procedural_Issue: Adequacy of reasons provided by officer
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet point requirements; request for discretionary review under section 76(3)
Outcome_on_Merits: No error in law or procedure found
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Decision found to be transparent and intelligible
Key_Evidence_Considered: Point score (65), sufficiency of points as indicator of economic establishment
Legal_Framework: Canadian immigration law, administrative law principles
Applicant_Challenge: Seeking substituted assessment under section 76(3) due to insufficient points
Legal_Rule_Source: Section 76(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Defendant_Response: Officer determined points were sufficient indicators; no substitution warranted
Legal_Provision: Section 76(3), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to meet minimum point threshold
Governing_Rule: Section 76(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
